thread.title: BOYS' TENNIS: No. 4 Devils claim another regional crown
thread.title_full: BOYS' TENNIS: No. 4 Devils claim another regional crown

author: greg.mengelt@newsandtribune.com(Greg Mengelt)
title: BOYS' TENNIS: No. 4 Devils claim another regional crown
text:
by Greg Mengelt 
SELLERSBURG â€” Fourth-ranked Jeffersonville won its third straight regional and its eighth in program history Wednesday. 
The title is also the sixth crown for Red Devil coach Mark Reilly after a 4-1 win over rival New Albany in the Silver Creek Regional championship. 
"I'm excited for Coach Reilly," junior Bradley Cross said. "He got another regional and we get to play Saturday." 
"It's definitely fun to represent the school," said sophomore Keith Asplund, who is playing in his first varsity postseason. "Now we get to play at semistate representing Jeff." 
The 20-0 Red Devils will face Evansville North (17-1) in Saturday's Jasper Semistate at noon. The unranked Huskies, who beat No. 29 Evansville Memorial in Tuesday's semifinal round, earned a 4-1 win over Evansville Mater Dei in Wednesday's Bosse Regional to advance to Jasper. 
Jeff will be a big favorite to advance to the state finals for the second straight season and the third time in six years. 
"It will be a good match," Cross predicted. "It's semistate." 
"You have to go out and play. Nothing's given," Asplund said. 
Kooper Falkenstein dropped the first two games of the opening set to New Albany junior Rohan Reddy at No. 2 singles Wednesday. Falkenstein then won the next 12 games for a 6-2, 6-0 victory to give Jeff an early 1-0 lead. 
Reilly said Falkenstein, who is now 25-0 on the season, may be the state's best No. 2 player. 
"We feel good about whoever we play, he's probably going to win at 2," Reilly said. "It gives our team confidence knowing that whoever we play, we can count on a point." 
Cross, who is now 20-1 at No. 3 singles, earned the Red Devils' easiest win of the day with a 6-0, 6-0 decision over New Albany freshman Noah Keeler. His win gave Jeff a 2-0 lead just moments after Falkenstein's triumph. 
"I feel like I played pretty good today," Cross said. "[Keeler] is young but he's good a lot of upside in front of him. It was a hard match, but I happened to come out with the win." 
Cross suffered from leg cramps in Tuesday's semifinal against Floyd Central. It was apparent early Wednesday there were no ill-affects. 
"We were really worried about him," Reilly said, "but there was no pain. He was fine in warmups, so I felt good about him. That was a strong key for us." 
It didn't take long after Falkenstein's and Cross's wins for the Red Devils to clinch the title. Almost immediately after those two singles' victories, Asplund and Blake Winchell completed a 6-3, 6-2 win over Ryan Robison and Logan Conrad in the No. 2 doubles match for Jeff's third win. 
"It's exciting to be the clinching point [for the regional title]," Asplund said. "I would say I played pretty well and I would say Blake played pretty well. We did what we needed to when we needed to." 
In the biggest surprise of the day, Jeff's 19-2 No. 1 doubles team of Sam Coward and Jack Reilly dropped the first set to New Albany's Jacob Stevens and Nate Johnson. As they did yesterday against Floyd Central, Coward and Reilly came back from a 6-2 loss in the first set to win in three sets. The Red Devil duo blanked the Bulldogs in the second set and won the third 6-1 after winning 11 straight games. 
"[New Albany] came out firing. They came out hot," Coward explained the first set. "We started to play our game and playing it well and we were able to come back in the second set and pull it out." 
Coach Reilly agreed with Coward's assessment. 
"Part of it was New Albany," Reilly said. "I think after losing yesterday [to Silver Creek's Nate Eckert and Jack Hawkins], they were hitting on all cylinders. They hit some great shots. [Coward and Reilly] moved on and didn't dwell on the past. We got up 2-0 in the second set and I think that relaxed us." 
New Albany coach Bob Dusch said he liked the way Stevens and Johnson responded after Tuesday's loss. 
"I was disappointed [Tuesday] in my 1 doubles," Dusch said. "[Wednesday] they realized they can play with these guys." 
New Albany's win came at No. 1 singles where 2013 News and Tribune Player of the Year Logan Charbonneau completed a surprisingly easy 6-1, 6-2 victory over Jeffersonville's Brock Winchell. 
Charbonneau stayed alive in the individual singles tournament with the conquest. 
"I played good today," he said. 
"I can't say enough about Logan," Dusch said. "I have to go back a long time to find someone with the mental focus that he has. He mentally gets tougher. I definitely think he's going to make some college a pretty good player." 
In spite of the loss, the Bulldogs showed they are capable of competing with one of the state's top teams. 
"I'm proud of our play," Charbonneau said. "We showed improvement from the first time we played Jeff. I'm proud of that." 
"I was very pleased," Dusch concurred. "Jeff's got a very fine team. I totally expect them to be at state. Today gave us a little indication that we can play right with them." 
New Albany is expected to six of its seven varsity players in 2016. The Bulldogs believe they will contend for the first regional title in program history. 
"Jeff loses a lot, Floyd loses a lot. Silver Creek's not playing a senior anywhere, so they're going to be a lot better," Dusch said. "I'm looking forward to it. These guys need to work and improve on some things. We came along a lot quicker than I thought we would this year." 
"Next year we're going to win it," Charbonneau predicted. 
Providence senior Landon Carrico advanced to today's individual Silver Creek Sectional championship with a 6-1, 6-0 over Corydon Central's Clayton Schreck. 
"I feel like I played well," Carrico said. "I feel like there are things I can improve, but overall, I thought I played well and got the [win]." 
Carrico faces Charbonneau today. The two split a pair of matches this season. The match could determine the 2015 News and Tribune Player of the Year. 
"Every play left is high quality and has proven themselves," Carrico said. "Obviously, I have to stay in A-plus form or I'm not going to be staying alive." 
"I want to win state," Charbonneau said. "I'm capable of it." 
SILVER CREEK REGIONAL 
CHAMPIONSHIP 
JEFFERSONVILLE 4, NEW ALBANY 1 
Singles: Logan Charbonneau (N) d. Brock Winchell 6-1, 6-2; Kooper Falkenstein (J) d. Rohan Reddy 6-2, 6-0; Bradley Cross (J) d. Noah Keeler 6-0, 6-0. 
Doubles: Jack Reilly-Sam Coward (J) d. Jacob Stevens-Nate Johnson 2-6, 6-0, 6-1; Blake Winchell-Keith Asplund (J) d. Ryan Robison-Logan Conrad 6-3, 6-2. 
INDIVIDUAL SECTIONAL CHAMPIONSHIP 
Landon Carrico (Providence) d. Clayton Schreck (Corydon) 6-1, 6-0 Sign Up / Sign In With
